For all your beamy out sides. Enter Cleanthe

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Heeres Cleanthes,
He comes to chide let him alone a little,
Our cause will be reveng'd, look, look his face
Is set for stormy weather, do but marke
How the Clouds gather in't, 'twil powre downe straight.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Me thinks I partly know you, thats my griefe
Could you not all be lost that had beene handsome,
But to be known at all tis more then shamefull,
Why was not yeur name wont to be Lisandr?

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: Tis so still coze.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Judgement dfer thy comming, else this mans miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: I told you there would be a showre anon.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Weel in and hide our noddles. Exeunt Courtiers & Eu∣genia.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: What Divel brought this colour to your mind.
Which since yur childhood I neare saw you weare
You were ever of an innocent gloss
Since I was ripe for knowledge, and would you lose it
And change the Livry of Saints and Angels
For this mixt monstrousnes, to force a ground
That has been so long hallowed like a Temple,
To bring forth fruits of earth now, and turn black
To the wild cries of lust, and the complexion
Of Sin in act, lost and long since repented;
Would you begin a work nere yet attempted;
To pul time bakward?
See what your wife wil do, are your wits perfect?

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: My witts.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: I like it ten times worse for t'ad been safer
Now to be mad, and more excusable.
I heare you dane gen and do strange follie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: I must confesse I have been put to some co

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: And yet you are not mad, pray say not so
Give me that comfort of you that you are mad
That I may think you are at worst, for if
You are not md, I then must guesse you have
The first of some Dsease wa never heard f,
Which may be worse then madness, and more fearfull,
Youd weep to see your selfe els, and your care
To pray wou'd quickly turne you white agen.
I had a father had he livd his month out
Bt to h seen this most prodigious folly,
There neded not the Law to have cut him off:
The sight of this had prov'd his executioner, and broke his heart,
He would have held it equall
Done to a Snctary, for what is age
Bt the holy place of life, Chapel of ease
For all mens wearied miseries, and to rob
That of her Ornament, it is accust,
As fom a Priest to steale a holy Vestment,
and convert it to a sinfull covering. Exit Lisnder.
I se ta's done him good, blessig go with it, Enter Eeia.
Such as may make him pure agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Twas bravely touch'd I faith sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: O y'are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Excedingly well handled.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Tis to you I come, he fell but i'my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: You mkd his beard Cosen.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Mk me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Did you ver see a haire so changd?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: I must be forcd to wake her lowdly to,
The Divel has rock'd her so fast asleep, Sumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: D you call sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Hw doe you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Be I nere so well
I must be sick of thee, th'art a Disease
That stickest t'oth heart, as all such women are.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: What ailes our kindred?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Blesse me she sleeps still, what a dead modesty is i'this womn?
Will never blush agen, look on thy work,
But with a Christian eye, 'twou'd turn thy heart
Into a showre of blood to be the cause
Of that old mns destruction, think upont
Ruine eternally, for through thy loose follies
Heaven has found him a faint servant lately,
His goodness has gone backward, and ingendred
With his old sins again, has lost his prayers
And all th tears that were companions with em
And like a blind fold man, giddy and blinded
Thinking he goes right on still, swerves but one foot
And turnes to the same place where he set out
So he that tooke his farwell of the world
And cst the joyes behind him out of sight,
Sum'd up his houres, made even with time and men
Is now in heart arriv'd at youth agen;
All by thy wildness thy too hasty lust
Has driven him to this strong apostacy,
Immodesty like thine was never equld
Ive heard of women, (shall I call em so)
Have welcomd suitors ere the Cops were cold,
But thou thy Husband living, thou art too bold.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Well have you done now si?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Look, look she smiles yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: All this is nothing to a mind resolvd,
Ask any woman that, shl ll you so much
You have only showne a pretty sawcy wit,
Which I shal not forget nor to rquite it,
You shal heare from me shortly:

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Shamelesse woman,
I take my counsel from thee tis too honest
And leave thee wholly to thy stronger master,
Besse the sex of thee from thee, thats my Prayer
Were al like thee so impudently common,
No man would be found to wed a woman. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Ile fit you gloriously hee that attempts to take away my pleasure,
Ile take away his joy, and I can sure
His conceald father payes ort, ile een tel.
Him that I meane to make my husband next Enter Simonides
And he shall tl the Duke, — Masse heere he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Hs had about with me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: What no? since sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: A lurt, a little flurt, he cald me strange names
But I neare minded him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: You shall quit him sir when he as little mind you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I like that wel.
I love to b revng'd when no one thinks of me.
Theres little danger that way,

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: This is it then
H you hall strike your troke shal be profound.
And yet your foe not gusle who gave the wound.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: A my troath I love to giv such wounds. Exu.

DIV1.HEAD: Act. IV. Scen. I.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Clowne, Burler, Bayliff, Taylor, Cooke, Drawer, Wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: VVEcome Gntlmen, will you not draw ere, will you drinke at Doe Gen∣tlemn?

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: O the Summer Ayres bst!

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: What Wine will ples you drink Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Declare sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo
SP.P: What y'are all sped already bullies?

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: My Wd lowes ah spitt and halfe ready lad, a turne or too more and I have done with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Then Cooke I hope you have basted her bfore this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: And stuck her with Rosemry too, to sweten h, she was tied er she came to my hnds what an old pece of flsh of fifty nine eleaven mooths and upwards, she must needs be flblown.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Put her off put her off, tho you lose by her the weathers hot.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Why Dawr? Enter Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: By and by, hee gentlemen, heeres the quintessence of Greece, the Sages never drunck better Grape.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P:
Sir the mad Greeks of this age a taste their Palermo
as well as the sage Greeks did before em, fill lick splggot.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Ad imum sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: My friends I must doubly invite you all the fifth of the next month, to the funerall of my first wife, and to the marriage of my second. my two to one this is she.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: I hope some of us wil bee ready for the funeral of our Wives by that time, to goe with thee, but shal they bee both of a day?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Oh best of al sir, where sorrow and joy meet together, one wil help away with another the better besides ther wil bee chages sv'd too the same Rosemary that serves for the Funeral, wil serve for the Wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: How long do you make account to be a Widdower sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Some halfe an houre, long enough a conscience.
Come, come, lets have some agillity, is there no Musick in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Yes sir, eere are sweet wire drawers in the howse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Oh tha makes them and you seldome part, you are wine drawers, and they wyer drawers.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: And both govern by the peg too.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: And ou hve pips in your consort too.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: And Sck-bts too sir.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: But the Heads of your Instruments diffr, yours are Hogs-heads their Cittern and Gittern Heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Bay.
SP.P: All wooden heads there they meet agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Bid em strike up, weel have a Dance, Gnothoes come hou shalt foole it too.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: No dancing with me, we have Siren heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Siren, twas Hiren the faire Greek man.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Five Drachmes of that, I say Siren the fair Greek, and so are all fair Greeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: A match, five Drachmes her name was Hiren.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Sirens name was Siren for 5. Drachmaes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Take heed what you do Gnothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Doe not I know our own Country women Siren and Nell of Greece, two of the fairest greeks that ever were.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: That Nel was Hellen of Greece too.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P:
As long as shee tarried with her Husband shee was Ellen, but after she came to Troy shee was Nel of Troy, or Bonny Nell
Whether you will or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Why did she grow shorer when she came to Troy?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Se grw longer if you marke the story, when she grew to be an ell sh was dep then any yard of Troy could reach by a quarter: there was Cressid was Troy waigh, and Nll was ha∣berdepoyse, she held more by fowre ounces then Cresida.

SP.SPEAKER: Bay.
SP.P: They say sh cusd mny wounds to be given in Troy

SP.SPEAKER: Clo
SP.P: True, she was wounded there her selfe, and cured againe by Plaster of Paris, and ver since that has beene usd to stop holes with. Enter Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw
SP.P: Gentlemen if you be disposed to bee merry, the Musick is ready to strike up, and heeres a conort of mad Greeks, I know not hether they bee men or women, or betweene both, they have wht yu call em vizards on their faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Vizards goodman lickspgot.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: If they be wise women they y be wizards too.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: They desire to enter amongst any merry company of Gentlemen good fel'owes for a traine or too. Old women.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Weel strain our slves with em say, let em come Gnothoes: now for the honou of Epire. Dance.

DIV1.STAGE: She dancing with me, we have Siren heere.
The Dance of old women mast, then offer to take the men they a∣gree all but Gnothoes: he fits with his Wench after tey whisper.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: I so kind ten every one his Wch to his seveall room Gnthoes we are all provided now as you are Exeunt each with his wf manet Gnothoes wife unmaskt.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I shall have two it seemes away I have Siren heere already

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: What a Mermaid?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: No but a maid horse face, oh o'd womn is it you?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Yes tis I, all the rest hve gud themselves, and taken their own wvs, and shall know that they have done more then they cn well answer, but I pray you, Husbn what are yo doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Fith thus shuld I do if thou weart dead old Ag. and thou hast not long to live me sure, we have Siren 'heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Art hou so shameless whilst I am living to keepe one un∣der my nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P:
Noe Ag I doe prize her far above thy nose, if tho wouldst lay me both hine eyes in my hand to boot, ile not lave her, ar
not ashamd to bee seene in a Tavern, and hast scarce a fortnight to live, oh old woman what art thou, must thou find no time to think of thy end?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Oh unkind villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: And then sweet heart thou shalt have two new gownes, and the best of this old old womans shall make thee rayments for the working ays.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Oh rascall dost thou quarter my clothes already too.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Her usfs will serve thee for nothing but to wash dishes, for thou shalt have nine of the new fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Impudent villaine, shamelesse harlot.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: You may heare she never wore any but railes al herlife time

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Let me come i'le teare the strumpet from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Darst thou call my wife strumpet, thou preterpluper∣fect tence of a woman, i'le make thee do penance in the sheet thou shalt be buried in, abuse my choice, my two to one.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: No unkind villaine i'le deceave thee yet,
I have a repreeve for five years of life,
I am with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Wench.
SP.P: Cud so Gnothoes ile not tarry so long, five yeares, I may bury two husbands by that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Alas give the poore woman leave to talke, she with child, I with a puppy, as long as I have thee by me, she shall not bee with child I warrant thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: The Law and thou and all shall find I am with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: i'le take my corporall oath I begat it not, and then thou diest for adultery.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: No matter that will aske some time in the proofe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Oh you'd bee stond to death would you, all old women would die a that fashion with all their hearts, but the Law shall overthrow you, the tother way first.

SP.SPEAKER: Wench.
SP.P: Indeed if it be so, I will not linger so long Gnotho.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Away, away, some botcher has got it, tis but a chushion I warrant thee, the old woman is loath to depart, she never sung o∣ther tune in her life.

SP.SPEAKER: Wench.
SP.P: Wee will not have our noses board with a chushion if it be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P:
Go, go thy wayes thou old Almanack, at the 28. day of December een almost out of date, down on thy knees, and make
the rea e of thy clothes to buy thee a Deaths head, and p upon thy mddle finger, your least considering Bawds doe so much; be not thou worse though thou art an old woman as she is, I am cloyd with oli stock fish, heers a yong perch is sweeter meat by halfe, prithee die before thy day if thou canst, that thou maist not be counted a witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: No, thou art a witch and i'le prove it, I said I was with child, thou knewst no other but by sorcery, thou saidst it was a cushion and so it is, thou art a witch fort, i'le be sworne too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, I told thee twas a chushion, go get thy sheet rea∣dy, wee'l see thee buried as we go to Churc to be married. Ex.
Nay i'le follow thee, and shew my selfe a wife, i'le plague thee as long as I live with thee, and i'le bury some money before I die that my ghost may hant thee afterward. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Whats that? oh nothing but the whispering wind,
Breaths through you churlish hathorne that grew rude
As if it chid the gentle breath that kist it,
I cannot be too circumspect, too carefull
For in these woods lies hid all my lives treasure,
Which is too much ever to feare to lose.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Though it be never lost, and if our watchfulness
Ought to be wise and serious against a thiefe
That comes to steale our goods, things all without us,
That proves vxtion often more then comfort,
How mighty ought our providence to be
To prevent those? if any such there were
That come to rob our bosome of our joyes,
That only makes poore man delight to live:
sh, i'me too fearful fie, fie, who can hurt me?
ut tis a general cowardice that shakes,
he nerves of confidence, he that hides treasure
magins every one thinks of that place
hen tis a thing lest minded, nay let him change
he place continually where ere it keeps,
There wil the feare keepe stil, yonders the store house Enter Hippolita.
Of all my comfort now, and see it sends forth
A deere one, to me, preious chiefe of women,
How does the good old soule, has he fed we?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Be rew me sir he made the heartiest meale to day
Much good may do i health.
A blessing on the,
Both for thy nwes and wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Eip.
SP.L: His stomack sir
Is betterd wondrously since his concealment.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Heaven has a blessed work int, come wee'r safe heere
I preethee cll him forth, the ayres much wholesomer.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Father,
How sweetly sounds the voyce of a good woman? Ent. Leonides.
It is so seldome heard that when it speaks
It ravishes all fences.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Lifts of honor,
Iv a joy weeps to see you, tis so full
So fairely fruitfull,
I hope to see you often and returne
Loaden with blessings, stll to powre on some
I find em all in my contented peace,
Ad lose not one in thousands, th'are disperst
So gloriously I know not which are brightest
I finde em as Angels are found by legions;
First in the love and honesty of a wife,
Which is the first and chiefest of all temporall blessings,
Next in your selfe, which is the hope and joy
Of all any actions, my affires, my wishes,
And lastly which crownes all, I find my soul
Crown'd with the peace of em, th'eternall riches
Mans only portion, for his heavenly marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Rise thou art all obedience, love and goodness,
I dare say that which thousand fathers cannot.
And thats my pretious comfort, never son
Was in the way more of celestiall rising,
Thou art so made of such ascending vertue
That all the powrs of hel cannot sinke thee. A Horn.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: What wast disturbd my joy?
Clean Did you not heare,
As a far off?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: What my excellent consort. Clean. Nor you.
I heard a — A Horne.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Harke agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Blesse my joy
What ales it on a sudden?
Now since lately.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Tis nothing but a symptome of thy care man.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Alas you do not heare well.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: What wast daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I heard a sound twice. A Horne.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Hark, lowder and nearer:
In for the precious good of virtue, quck sir.
Lowder and nearer yet, at hand at hand;
A hunting heere tis strange, I never
Knew game followed in these woods before.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Duke, Simonides, Courtiers, and Executioner.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Now let em come and spare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Ha, tis, ist not the Duke, look sparingly?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Tis he but what of that, alas take heed sir,
You care will overhrow us.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Come. it shall not,
Lets set a pleasant fce upon our feares,
Though our hers shake with horror, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Harke.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Pithee proceed,
Ime taken with these light things infinitely,
Sice the old mans deceae; ha so they parted, ha, ha. ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Wh ow should I beleeve this, look, hees merrry
As if h had no such chrge? one with that care
Could never be so still, he holds his temper,
And tis the same still with no difference
He brought his fathers Corps to'h grave with,
He laught thus then you know.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: I, he may laugh my Lord;
That sower but how he glories in his cunning,
And perhaps done more to advance his wit,
Then to expresse affection to his father,
That onely he hs over reach'd the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: He tels you right, my Lord, his owne Cosen germen
Rveald it first to me, a free tongu'd woman,
And very excellent at telling secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: If a contempt can be so neatly carried,
It gives me cause of wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Troath my Lord,
Twill prove a delicat cosoning, I believe:
I'de have no Scrivener offer to come neere it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: My lov'd Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Not mov'd a whit,
Costant to lightning still, tis strange to meet you
Upon a ground so unfrequented sir:
This dos not fit your pssion, your for mirth
Or I mstk you much.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: But finding it
Grow to a noted imperfection in me,
For any thing too much is vitious;
I come to thes disconsolate walkes, of purpose
Onely to dul and take away the edge ont.
I ever had a greater zale to sadnesse,
A naturall proportion, I cofffe my Lord
Bfore that cheerful accident fel out
If I may call a fathers funeral cheerful
Wihout wrong done to duty or my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: seemes then you take pleasure 'these walks sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Contemplative content I do my Lord
They bring into my mind oft meditations
o sweetly pretious, that in the parting
find showre of grace upon my cheeks,
They take their leave so feelingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: So sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Which is a kind of grave delight my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: And 've small cause Cleauthes t'afford you he least delight that has name.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Now it begins to fadge.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.P: Peace thou art so greedy Sim.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: In your excesse of joy you have exprest
our rancor and contempt aganst my Law:
our smiles deserve fining, y'ave profest
Derision openly een to my face,
Whch might be death a littl more incensd
You do not come for any freedome heere
But or a project of your own,
But ll tht knowne to be contentfull to thee,
Shall in th use prove deadly, you lies min
If ever thy presumption do but led thee
Into thee walkes agen, or that womn
I'le have em watchd a purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: Now now, his colour ebbs and flowe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Marke hers too.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Oh who shall bring food to the poor old man now,
Speak somwhat good sir or wee'r lost for ever?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Oh you did wondros ill to call me agen
There are not words to help us if I intreat
Tis found, that will betray us worse then silence
Prithee let Heaven alone, and les say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: Y'av struck em dumb my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Look how guilt looks.
I would not have that feare upon my flesh
To save ten fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: He is safe still, is he not?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Oh you do ill to doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Thou'art all goodnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Now does your grace believe?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Tis too apparent
Search, make a speedy search, for the imposure
Cannot be far off by the feare it sends.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Hs the Lapwings cunning, i'me afraid my Lor
That cries most when shees farthest from the nest.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Oh wee'r betrayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Betrayd sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: See my Lord,
It comes out more and more still. Exeunt Courtiers Si.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Bloody theefe,
Come from that plae, tis sacred-homicide,
Tis not for thy adulterate hands to touch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Oh miserable vertue, what distresse art thou in at this mi∣nute?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Help me thunder
my powers lost, Angels shoot plagues and help me:
Why are these men in health and I so hear sick?
Or why should nature have that power in me
To leavy up a thousand bleeding sorrowes
And not one comfort, onely makes me lie
Like the poore mockery of an Earthquake heere?
Panting with horror, and have not so much force in all my venge∣ance.
To shake a villain off a mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Use him genly and Heaven will love you fort.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Father, oh Father now I see thee full
In thy affction, thou'rt a man of sorrow
Bu reverntly becomst it, that' my comfort.
Extremity was never better grac'd
Then with that looke of thine, oh let me look still
For I shll lose it, all my joy and strength
Is een Ecclips'd together, I transgrest
Your Law my Lord, let me receive the sting on
Be once just sir, ad let the offnder die
Hees innocent in all, and I am guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Your grace knowes when affction only speks
Truth is not alwaies there, his love would drw
An undeservd misery on his youth,
And wrong a peace resolv'd, on both parts sinfull;
Tis, I am guilty of my owne concealment
And like a worldly coward injurd heaven
Wih feae to go toot, now I see my fault,
And am prepard with joy to suffer fort.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Go give him qick dispatch, let him see death
And your presumption sir shall come to judgement. Exeunt with Leonides.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Hees going, oh hees gon sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Let me rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Why doe you not then, and follow?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: I strive fort
Is heir no hand of pitty that will ease me
And take this villine from my heart a while?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Alas hees gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: A worse supplies his place then,
weight more pondrous, I cannot follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Oh misery of afflicion.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: They will stay
Till I can come, they must be so good ever
Though they be nere so cruell,
My lst lev must tken think a that,
And this lst blessing given, I will not lose
That for a thosand consorts.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: That hopes wretched.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: The inutterable stings of fortune,
All greefs are to be borne, save this alone;
This like a headlong torrent over turnes the frame of nature,
For he that gives us life first, as a father,
Locks all his naturall sufferings in our blood, to
The sorrows that he feels, are our heads,
They are incorporate to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Noble sir.
Let me behold him well.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Thou shouldst be good,
Or tho'urt a dangerous substance to be lodgd
So near the heart of man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: What means this, deere sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: To thy trust onely was this blessed secret
Kindly committed, tis dstroy'd, thou seest
What followes to be thought ont.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Mserable;
Why heers th'unhappinesse of woman stil,
That having forfeited in old times their trust Enter Eugenia.
Now makes their faiths suspcted that are just.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: What shal I say to all my sorrowes then,
That looke for satisfaction?

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, Cozen

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: How ill dost thou become this time?

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Ha. ha, ha.
Why thats but your opinion, a yong wench
Becomes the time at all times.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Now coze wee'r even, and you be remembred
You left a Strumpet and a whore at home with me,
And such fine field bed words, which coul not cost you
Lesse then a fther.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Is it come that way?

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Had you an Uncle
He should goe the same way too.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Oh eternity
What monster is this feind in labour with?

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: An asse Coult with two heads, thats she and you:
I will not lose so glorious a revenge.
Not to be understood int: I betray him,
And now wee'r even, y'ad best keepe you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Is there not poyson yet enough to kill me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Oh sir, forgive me, it was I betrayd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: The fellow of my heart twill speed me then.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Her tears that never wept, and mine owne pitty
Een cozend me together; and stole from me
This secret, which fierce death should not have purchast.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Nay then wee'r at an end, all we are false ones,
And ought to suffer, I was false to wisdome
In trusting woman, thou wert false to faith
In uttering of the secret, and thou false
To goodnesse in deceaving such a pitty:
We are all tainted some way but thou worst,
And for thy infectious spots ought to die first.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Pray turne your weapon sir upon your Mistress,
I come not so ill friended; rescue servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Are you so whorishly provided?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Yes sir she has more weapons at command then one.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Put forward man, thou art most sure to have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I shall be surer if I keepe behind though.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Now servants shew your loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I'le shew my love too a farr off.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: I love to be so courted, woe me there.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I love to keep good weapons though nere fought
I'me sharper set within then I am without.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Oh Gentlemen Cleanthes.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Fight, upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Thy thirst of blood proclaimes thee now a Strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Tis daintie, next to procreation fiting,
de either be dstroying men or getting. Enter Officers

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Officer.
SP.L: Forbeare on your allegiance gentlemen
Hees the Dukes Prisoner, and we ceise upon him
To answer this contempt against the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: I obey Fate in ll things.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Happy rescue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: I would y'ad seis'd vpon him a minute sooner, tad sav'd me a cut finger, I wonder how I came bi't, for I never put my hand forth i'me sure, I think my own sword did cut it if truth were knowne; may be the wier in the handle, I have liv'd these five and twenty yeares and never knew what cullour my blood was before I nvr durst eat Oysters, nor cut peck loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: You have showne your spirits gentlemen, but you
Have cut your finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I the wedding finger too, pox ont.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.P: Youl prove a bawdy batchelor Sim, to have a cut up∣on your finger, before you are married.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I'le never draw sword agen to have such
A jest put upon me. Exeunt

DIV1.HEAD: Act. V. Scen. I.

STAGE.HI: Sword and Mace carried before thm.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: BE ready with your Prisoner, weel t nstntly n rise before leaven, or when we plse: Shall we not o low udges?

SP.SPEAKER: Cour.
SP.L: Tis committed
All to our power, censure and pleasure, now
The Duk hath made us cheef Lords of this Sessions,
And we may speake by fits, or sleep by turnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Leave that to us, but what so re we do
The Prisoner shall be sure to be condemnd,
Sleeping or waking we are resolvd on that
Before we set upon him. Eugenia.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Make you question
If not Cleanthes and one enemy
Ny a concealor of his father too.
A vild example in these dayes of youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: If they were given to follow such examples
But sure I think they are not, how so ere
'Twas wickedly attempted, thas my judgement
And it shll passe whilst I am in power to sit,
Never by Pince were such yong judges mde,
But now the cause rqires it, if you marke it
He must make yong or none for all the old ones
Her father he hath sent a fishing, and my fathers one
I humbly thanke his Highness. Enter Eugenia

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: Widdows?

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: You almost hit my name, no Gentlemen
You come so wondrous neare it I admire you
For your Judgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: My wife that must be she.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: My husband goes upon his last houre now.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: On his last legs I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: September the seventeenth
I will not bate an houre ont, and to morrow
His latest houres expired.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Bring him to judgement,
The juries panneld and the verdict given
Ever he appears we have tane course for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: And Officers to attach the gray yong man,
The yoth of fourscore be of comfort :
We shall no longer bosome January:
For that I will take order, and provide
For you a lusty Aprill. Lisander and Guardian.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: The month that ought indeed
To go before May.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: Doe as we have sayd,
Take a strong guard and bring him into Court,
Ldy Eugenia see this charge performed
That having his life forfeitd by the Law
Hee may relieve his soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Willingly
From shaven chinns never came better Justice
Then these new tucht by rason.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: What you doe
Doe suddenly wee charge you, for we purpose to make but a short
Sssions, a new business Enter Hippolia.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: The faire Hippolia, now whats your suits?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Alas I know not how to stile you yet,
To call you judges doth not suit your yeares
Nor heads and braines shew more antiquity,
Yet sway your selves with quity and tuth
And i'le poclime you rverent, and repeat
Once in my life ime I have seene grve heads
Plac't upon yong mens shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Hark she slus us,
And thinks to make us monstrous.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip
SP.L: Prove not so,
For yet me thinks you beare the shapes of men.
Though nothing more then meerly beautifeaus
To make you appeare Angels, but if Crimson
Your name and power with blood and crulty,
Suppess faire virtue and enlarge of old vice,
Both against Heaven and Nture, draw your sword
Mke either will or humor turn the soule
Of your created greatnsse, and in that
Oppose all goodnesse. I must tell you there
Y're more then monstrous, in the very act,
You change your selfe to Dvils.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: Shee a witch
Hake she begins to conjure

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Time you see
Is short much business now on foot, shall I
Give her her answer?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: None upon the Bench
More learnedly can do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: He, he, hem, then list
I wonder at thine impudence yong huswife
That thou dast plead for such a base offender,
Conceale a father past his time to die:
What son and heire would have done this but he?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: I vow not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Because yee are paricides
And how can comfort be derived from such
That pitty not their fathes?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.P: You are fresh and faire, practise yong womens ends when husbands are distrest provide them friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I'le st him forward fee thee
Some wives would pay for such a curtesie. without fee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Times of amzement what duty goodness dwell,
I soaught for charity but knock at Hel. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Eugenia, with Lisander Prisoner, a Gurd.

SP.SPEAKER: Simonides.
SP.L: Eugenia com.
Command a scond guard
To bring Cleanthes in weel not sit long.
My stomack strives to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Now servants may a Lady be so bold
To call your power so low?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: A Mstriss may,
She can make all things low, then in that languge
There can be no offnce.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: The times now come
Of manumissions take him into bonds,
And I am then at freedome.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: This the mn,
He hath left of lte to feed on snakes,
His berds turnd white again

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Court.
SP.L: Ist possible these gowty legs danc't lately,
And shatterd in a Glliard?

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Jealousie,
And fear of death can worke strange prodigies.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: The nimble Fencer this that made me tear
And traverse bout the Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I and gave me
Those elbow Halths the hangman take him fort:
They had almost fetcht my heart out, the Dutch Veny
I swallowed pretty wel, but the halfe pike
Had almost prepard me but had I took
Being swolne I had cast my Lungs out. Florish.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: A flemish Enter the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Peace the Duke.
Nay bae yur seats, whose that?

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: May't plese yur Highness

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Tis old Lisander.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: And brought in by his wife a worthy president
Of one tht no way would offend the Law.
And shoul not passe away without remark,
You hv ben lookt for long.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: But never fit
To die till now my Lord, my sins and I
Hve been but newly parted, much a do
I had to get them leave me, or be taught
That difficult lesson how to learn to die.
I never thought there had been such an act
And tis the only discipline we are borne for
All studdies as are, are but as circular lines
And deah the center where they must all meet.
I now can looke uppon thee erring woman
And not be vext with jealousie, on yong men,
And no way envy their delicious healh,
leasure and strength, all which were once mine owne
And mine must be theirs one day.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: You have tamd him

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: And know how to dispose him that my Liege
Hath been before detrmined, you confesse
Your selfe of full age.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: Yes and prepard to inheit

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Your place above—Duke—away to death with him

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Of which the hangmans strength Cleanthes Guard.
Shall put him in possession, tis still guard
To take me willing and in mind to die.
And such are when the earth growes weary of them
Most fit for heaven, the Court shall make his Mittimus
And send him thither presently ith mean time.
SP.STAGE: Enter a Guard with Cleanthes, Hippollita weeping after him.
SP.L: So see another person brought to the Barr.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: The arch Malefactor.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: The grand offenders the most refractory
To call good orders, tis Cleanthes,
Hee.
That would have sons grave fathers ere their fathers
Be sent unto their graves.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: There will be expectation
In your severe pooceedings against him;
His act being so Capitall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Fearfull and bloody,
Therefore we charge these women leave the Court
Lest they should stand to heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: I in expectation
Of a most happy freedome. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I with the apprehension
Of a most sad and desolate widdow hood. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: We bring him to the Bar.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Hold up your hand sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: More reverence to the place then to the person
To the one I offr up a palm
Of duty and obedience showd us to heaven,
Imploring justice which was never wanting
Upon that Bench whilst their own fathers sat:
But unto you, my hands contracted thus,
As threatning vengeance against murtherers,
For they that kill in thought shed innocent blood
With pardon to your highness too much passion
Made me forget your presence and the place,
I now am cald too

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: All one Majesty
And Power we have to pardon or condemne
Is now conferd on them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: And these weel use
Little to thine advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: I expect it
And as to these I look no mercy from
And much lesse showne to intreat it, I thus now
Submit me the Emblemes of your power I meane
The Sword and Bench but my most reverend judges
Ere you proceed to sentence, for I know
You have given me lost, will you resolve me one thing?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: So it be breefly questioned.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Shew our honor,
Dy spends it selfe a pace.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: My Lords it shll
Resolv me then where are your filliall tears
Your muning habits and sad herts become.
Tht ould ttend your fathers funerall
Though the stick Lw which I will not accuse
Bcause a sujct snatcht away their lives
It doth not bar them to lament their deaths
O if you cannot spre one sd suspire
It doth not bid you laugh them to their graves
Ly subtle traines to antidate their yeares,
To be the sooner ceas'd of their estates.
Oh time of age wheres that Eneas now
Who letting all his Jewels to the flmes.
Forgetting country kindred treasure friends
Fotunes and all things save the name of son
Which you so much forget, goe like Eneas
Who tooke his bedrid father on his back
And with that sacred load (to him no buden)
Hewd out his way through blood, through fire, through
Even all the armed streets of bright burning Troy,
Onely to sae a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: We have no leasure now
To heare lessons read from Virgill, wee are past schoole,
And all this time thy judges.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Tis fit,
That we proceed to sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: You ae the mouth
And now tis fit to open.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Justice indeed
Should ever be close ear'd, and open mouthd
That is to heare him little, and speake much
Low then Cleanthes there is none can be
A good son and a bad subject, for if Princes
Be cald the peoples fathers then the subjects
Are all his sones, and he that flouts the Prince
Doth disobey his father, there yeare gone.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: And not to be recovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: And again.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: If he be gone once call him not againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I say againe this act of thine exprses
A double disobedience, as our Princes
Are fathers, so they are our soveraignes too,
And he that doth rebell against soveraignety
Doth commit treason in the height of degree
And now thou art quite gone.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: Our brother in commssion
Hath spoke his mind both learnedly and neatly,
And I can add but little, howsoever
It shall send him packing.
He that begins a fult that wants example
Ought to be made example for the fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: A faul no longer can I hold my selfe
To heare vice upheld and vertue throwne downe
A fult judge then, I desire where it lyeth
In those hat are my judges or in mee
Heaven stnd on my side pitty love and duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Where are they sir who ees them but your slfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Not you, and I am ure,
You never had he gracious eyes to see them,
You think you arraigne me, but I hpe
To sentence you at the Bar.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: That would shew brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: This were the judgement seat, we now
The heavist crimes that ever made up
Unaurallness in humanity,
You are found fowle and guilty by a Jury
Mde of your fathers curses, which have brought
Vengeance impending on you, and I now
Am forst to pronounce judgement on my judges.
The common Lawes of reason and of nature
Condemne you ipso facto, you are paricides,
And if you marry will beget the lyar
Who when y'are growne to full maturity
Will hurry you their fathers to their graves;
Like Traytors you take counsell from the living
Of upright judgement, you would rob the Bench:
Experience and dicretion snatcht away
From the earth face, turne all into disorder,
Imprison vertue, and infranchice vice,
And put the Sword of justice into the hands of
Boyes and mad men.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Well, well have you done sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: I have spoke my houghts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Then 'le begin and end.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Tis time I now begin,
Where your commissin nds,
Cleantes you come from the Br
Bcase I know y'are sevrally disposd;
I heere invite you to an objct will no doubt Recorders. Old men.
Worke in you contray ffcts.
Musick.

DIV1.STAGE: Musick, Sons and the old men appeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Pray Heaven I dream not, sure he moves, talkes comforta∣bly, as joy can wish a man, if he be changd
Fr above from me, he is not ill intreated
His face doth promise fullness of content
Ad glory hath a parint.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: You tha can claime acquintance with these lads
Talke freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: I can see none there thats worth one hand to you from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: These are thy judges and by their grave Law
I find thee clear, but thse Delinquents guilty:
You must change placs for tis so decred
Such just preheminence hath thy goodness gaind
Thou art the juge now, they the men arraignd.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: Hers fine dancing Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cour.
SP.L: Is hy father amongst them?

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Oh a Pox I saw him the first thing I lookt on
A live againe, flght I believe now a father
Hth as mny lives as a mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Tis full as blessed as tis wonderfull
Oh bring me back to the same law againe
I am fowler then all these, cease on me Officers
And bing me to new sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Whats all this?
A fault not to be pardoned
Unnaturallness is but suns shaddow to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I am glad of that, I hope the case may alter
And I turne judge againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: Nme your offnce.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: That I should be so vild
As once to think you cruell.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk
SP.L: Is that all?
'Twas prdond ere confest, you that have sons
If they be worthy heare my challenge then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: I should hve one amongst them had he had grace
To have retaind that name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim
SP.L: I pray you Father. Kneeles.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: That name I know
Hth been long since forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I find but small comfort in remembring it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Cleanthes take your places with these grave father
And read what in that table is inscribed
Nw set these at the Br.
And read Clanthes to the dread and terror
Of disobedience and unnaturall blood.
It is decreed by the grave and learned
Counsell of Epire, that no son and heire
Shall be held cpble of his inheritance
A h age of one and twenty, unlesse he be at that time
As natue in obedience, manners and goodnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Sure I shall never be at full age then,
hough I lve to an hundred years, and thats nearer by twenty,
hen the lat Statute allowd.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cour.
SP.L: A terrible act.
SP.P: Moreover is encted that all sons aforesaid, whom either this Law or their one grac, whom it shll reduce into the true method of uty, vertue and affction; and relate their triall and approbation from Cleantes the Son of Leonides— from m my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: Fm none but you as fullest, proceed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.P:
Whom for his manifest vertues, we mke such
judge and censure of youth and the absolute reffrenc of life and manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: This is a brave world, when a man should be
Selling Land he must be learning manners,
Ist not my Msters? Eugenia.
Whts heere to do, my suitors at the Brr
The old baud shines againe, oh miserable! She sounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Read the Law over to her twill awake her
Tis one deseves smll pitty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.P: Lstly it is ordined that all such wives now whtsoe∣ver that shall designe the husbands death to bee soone rid of them and entertaine suitors in their husbands life time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: You had best read that a little lowder.
For if any thig that will brig her to her selfe againe, and finde her tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.P: Shll not presume on the penalty of our heavy displea∣sure to mry within ten years fter.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Tha Lwes too long by nine years and a halfe.
I'le take m death upont, so shall mst womn.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: And those icontnent women so ffnding
To be judge and censured by Hippolita,
Wife to Cleanthes. Hippolita.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.P: Of all the rest i'le not be judge by her. Enter Hip.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.P: Ah heere shee comes, let mee prevent thy joyes, prevent them but in part and hide the rest, thou hast not strength enough to beare them else.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Leonides. Shee faints.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: I feared it all this while.
I knew was past thy power Hipolita,
What contrariety is in womens blood?
One faints for spleene and anger, shee for gace.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Of Sons and Wives we see the worst and bst,
My future ages yeeld Hippolitas
Mny, but few like thee Eugenia.
Let no Simonides henceforth have a fame
But all blst sons live in Cleantes name Musick.
Ha what strange kind of melody was that?
Yet give it entrance whatsoere it be. Musick
This day is all deout to liberty.

DIV1.STAGE: Clo. &c. Enter Musick one carrying a Brideak, the Clewe, the rest wih tm ol Womn.
Enter Clowne, and Wnch, the rst wih the old women, the Clownes wife, Msick, and a Bide Cake the wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Fidlers crowd on, crowd on, let no man lay a block in your way, crowd on I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Stay the crowd a while, lets know the eason
Of this jollity.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.P: Sirrah doe you know where you ar?
Yes sir, I am heere, now here, and now heere agen sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ais.
SP.P: Your hats too high crownd the Duke in presnce.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: The Duke (as hee is my Soveraigne) I doe give him two Crownes for it, and thats quall change all the wold over, am Lord of the day (being my marriage day the second) I doe ad∣vance-bonnet crowd on a fore.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Good sir a few words if you'l vouchsafe em
Or will ou be forc'd?

SP.P: Forc'd, I wul te Duke himselfe would say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: I think he dares sir, and does, if you stay not
You shll be forc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I thinke so my Lord, and good reason too, shall not I stay when your gace sayes I shall, I were unworthy to bee a Bride∣groom in any part of your Highness Dominions then, will it please you to tast of he wedlock courtesie?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Oh by no manes sir, you shall not deface
So faire an onament for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: If your grace please to be cacted say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: And which might be your faire Bride sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: This is m two for one that must be uxor uxoris,
The remedy doloris, and the very syceum Amoris.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: And hast hou any else?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I have n older my Lord for other uses.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: My Lord I doe observe a strange decorum heere
These that do lead this day of jollity
Doe march wih Musick and most mirthfull cheeks
Those that doe follow sad, and wofully
Nearer the havior of a funerall
Then a wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: Tis tre, pray expound that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo
SP.P: As the dstiny of the day falls out my Lord, one goes out to wedding another goes to hanging; and your Grace, in the due consideration shall finde em much alike, the one hath the ring upon her finger, the other a halter about her neck.
I take thee Beatrice sayes the Bridegroome, I take thee Agatha sayes the hangman, and both say together to have and to hold till death do prt us.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: his is not yet plaine enough to my understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: If further your Grace examine it, you shall find I shew my selfe a dutifull subject and obedient o the Lw, my selfe (with these my good friends, and your good subjects) our old wives whse daies are ripe, and their lives forfeit to the Law onely my selfe more forward then the rest, am already provided of my se∣cond choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Oh take heede sir, you'l run your selfe into danger,
If the Law inds yo with two wives at once
Teres a shewd premunre.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I have taken leave of the ol my Lod. I have nothing to sy to her, shes going to S, you Gace knowes whether better thn I doe, shee hs a strong wind with her, it stands full in her poope when you please let her disemboge.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: And the rst of her neighbours with her whom wee pre∣sent to th satisfaction of your Highnes Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Ad so we take our leaves and leave them to your High∣ness, croud on.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Stay. stay, you are too forward, will you marry?
And your wife ye lving.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Alas Shel bee dead bfore wee can get to Church, if your Gace wuld set her in the way, I would dispatch her, I have a vnter on, which woud returne mee, if your Highnes would mke a littl moe hst two for one.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Com my Lods we must sit agen, heers a Case
Cves a mos srious censue.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Nw ty shall be dispatcht out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: wuld they were gone once, the time goes away.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: Wich is the wife unto the forward Bidegroome?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: I am and it please your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Tust me a lusty woman, able bodied
And well blooded cheeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Oh she paints my Lord, she was a Chamber Maid once, and learnt it of he Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: Sure I think she cannot be so old.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Truly I think so too, and please your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Two to one with your grace of that, shees threescore by th Book.
Peace sirra y'are to loud.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Take heed Gnhoes if you moove the Dukes patience, tis an edge toole but a word and a blow, he cut off your head.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Cu ff my head, away ignorant, hee knowes it cost more in the haire, he does not use to cut off many such heads as mine, I will talke to him to, it he cut off my head, le give him my eares, I say my wife is at full age for the Law, the Clark shall take his oath and the Church Book shall be sworne too.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: My Lords, I leave this snsue to yu

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Then fist this fellow does deserve punishment
For offring up a lusty able woman
Which may do srvce to the commonwealth,
Where the Law craves one impotnt and useless.

SP.SPEAKER: Creon,
SP.L: Therefore to be severely punished
For thus attempting a second marriage
His wife yet livinge.
Nay to have it trebled
That even the daye and instant when he should mourne
As a kind husband to her funerall,
Hee leds a triumph to the scorne of it
Which unseasonable joy ought to bee punished
With all sverity.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: The fiddles will be in a foule case too by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Nay further it semes hee has a venter
Of two for one at his second marriage
Which cannot be but a conspiracie
Against the former.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: A messe of wise old men.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Sirrah what can you answer to all these?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P:
Ye'are good old men and talke as age will give you leave; I would speake with the youthfull Duke himselfe, hee and I may
speake of things that shall be 30 or 40 yeares after you are dead and rotten, aas you ae heere to day and gone to Sa to morrow.

SP.L: Introath sir then I must be paine with you
The Law tha should take away your old wife from you
The which I do pceive wa your dsire,
Is voyd ad frustate so for the rst,
There as been since another arliament
Has cut it off.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I see your gace is disposd to be plasant.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Yes you might perceive that, I had not else
Thus dallied with your follies.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Ile talke further with your grace when I come
Bacl from Church, in the meane time you know what to doe
With the old womn.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Say sir unlesse in the man time you mean
I cuse a bber to be set up in your way
d hng yu at your reurn.

SP.SPEAKER: Wise.
SP.P: Oh gatious Pice.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk
SP.L: Your old wives cannot die to dy by any
w of mine, for ought I can say too em
y may by a new edict buy you,
nd then perhaps you pay a new fine too.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: This is fine indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Oh Gacious rince my he live a hudred years more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook
SP.P: Your vntue i not like to come in to day Gnotoes.
Gv me the principll back.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook,
SP.P: Nay by my roath weel venter still, and i'me sure wee have as ill a venter of it as you, for wee have taken old wives of pupos, where that we had thught to have put away at this mar∣ket, now we cannot utter a penyworth.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Wll sirrah you were bst to discharge
Your new chage and take you od one to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Oh Muick, no musick, but prove most dolefull Trumpets,
Oh Bride no Bride, but thou mst prove a Strumpet,
Oh venter, no venter, I have for one now none,
Oh wife, thy life is sv'd when I hope t'had been gone,
Case up your fruitlss strings. no pnny no wedding,
Case up thy Maiden head, no Priest no bedding,
Avant my venter it can nere be restord,
Till Agg my old wife be thrown over board,
Then come agen old Agg since it must be so,
Let Bride, and venter with wofull Musick goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: What for the Bride cake Gnothoes?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Let it be mouldy now tis out of season,
Let it grow out of date currant and reason,
Let it be chip'd and chopt and given to chickens
No more is got by that, then William Dikins
Got by his wooden dishes.
Put up your plums as fidlers put up pipes,
The Wedding dasht the Bridegroome
Weeps and wipes.
Fidlers farwell and now without perhaps,
Put up your Fiddles as you put up scraps.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: This passion has given some satisfaction yet,
My Lord I think you'l pardon him nw,
Withall the rst so they live honestly
With the wives they have.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: Oh mst freely, free pardon to all.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: I wee have deserv'd our pardons if wee can live honstly with such reverent wives that have no motion in em but their tongues.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Heaven blesse your Grace, y'are a just Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: All hopes dash'd, the Clarks duties lost, Venter gon, my second wife divorc'd, and which is worst the old one come back agen.
SP.L: Such Voyages are made now adayes, I will weep too salt
Of our nose, besides these two fountaines of fresh water,
Your grace had been more kind to your yong subjects.
Heaven blsse, and mend your Lwes, that they do
Not gull your poore Country men: fashion, but I am nt
The fist by forty that hs been undone by he Lw,
Tis but a folly to stand upon Termes,
SP.P: I take my leave of your Grace, as well as mine eyes will give me lave, I would they had been a sleep in their beds when they opend em to see this day: come Agg, come Agg.

SP.SPEAKER: Creon
SP.P: Were not you all my servants?

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: Dring your life as we thought sir, but our yong Master turnd us way.

SP.SPEAKER: Creon.
SP.P: How headlong villaine wert thou in thy ruine?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I followed the fashion sir as other yong men did,
If you have as we thought you had been
We should nere have coe for this I warrant you,
We did not feed after the old fashion on Beefe
And Mutton and such like.

SP.SPEAKER: Creon.
SP.L: Well what dammage or charge you have run
Your selves into by marriage, I cannot help
Nor deliver you from your wves, them you must keepe
Your selves hall againe retaine to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: We thank your Lordship for your love, and must thanke our selves for our bad bargains.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Cleanthes You delay the power of Law,
To be inslicted on these misgovernd men,
That filiall duty have so far transgrest.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean
SP.L: My Lord I see a satisfaction
Meeting the sentence, even preventing it
Beating my words back in their utterance
See sir theres salt sorrow bringing forth fresh
And new dutles (as the sea propgat)
The Elephnts have found their joynts too, why
Hres humility able to bind up
The puishing hands of the severest masters
Much more the gentle fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: I had nere thought to have been brought so low as my knees agen, but since thers no remedy, fathers, reverent fathers, as you ever hope to have good sons and eirs, a handfull of pitty wee confesse wee have deservd more then wee are willing to receive at your hands, though sonnes can never deserve too much of their fa∣thers as shall appeare afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Creon
SP.L: And what way can you decline your feeding now?
You cannot retire to Beeves and Muttons sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Alas sir you see a good pattern for that, now we have laid by our high and lusty meats, and are downe to our may bones allrea∣dy.

SP.SPEAKER: Creon.
SP.L: Well sir rise to vertues weel bound you now,
You that were too weake your selves to govern,
By others shall be governd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: Cleanth,
I meet your Justice with reconcilement
If there be tears of faith in womans brest
I have receivd a mirriade which confirmes me
To finde a happy renovation.

SP.SPEAKER: Clean.
SP.L: Heers Virtues Throne
Which i'le imbellish with my dearest Jewels
Of Love and Faith, Peace and Affction,
This is the Altar of my Sacrifice,
Where dayly my devoted knees shall bend
Age honored shrine, time still so love you,
That I so long may have you in mine eye
Untill my mmory lose your beginning.
For you great Prince, long may your fame survive,
Your justice and your wisdome never die,
Crowne of your Crowne, the blessing of your Land
Which you reach to her from your regents hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Oh Cleanthes had you with us tasted
The entertainment of our retirement
Feard and exclaimd on in your ignorance,
You might have sooner died upon the wonder
Then any rage or passion for our losse.
A place at hand we were all strangers in
So sphead about with Musik, such delights
Viands and attendance, and once a day
So cheared with a royall visitant
That oft times (waking) our unsteady phantasies
Would question whether we yet livd or no
Or had possssion of that Paradice
Where Angels be the guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Enough Leonides
You go beyond the prase, we have our end
And all is ended well, we have now seene
The flowers and weeds that grew about our Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: If these be weeds i'me afraid I shall weare none so good a∣gen as long as my father lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Only this Gentleman we did abuse
With our owe bosome we seemd a Tyrant
And he our instrument looke tis Cratilus. Discover the Excutioner.
The man that you suppos'd had now been traveld,
Which wee gave leave to learn to spak
And bring us forraigne languges to Greece
Alls joyed I see, let Musick be the rone,
And set it high, the good needs feare no Law,
It is his safety, and the bad mans aw.

DIV1.HEAD: An Exact and perfect CATALOGUE of all the PLAIES that were ever printed; together, with all the Authors names; and what are Comedies, Histories, Interludes, Masks, Pa∣storels, Tragedies: And all these Plaies you may either have at the Signe of the Adam and Eve, in Little Britain; or, at the Ben Johnson's Head in Thredneedle-street, over against the Exchange.

ROW.CELL: Changes, or love in a maze
Choice a good wife from a bad
Endimion, or the man in the moon
Enough as good as a feast
Henry the Fifth, with the battel
If this be not a good play the de∣vils in't
Iohn K. of England, both parts
Knack to know an honest man
New way to pay old debts
New trick to cheat the divel
Rule a wife and have a wife
See me, or see me not
The longer thou livest, the more fool thou art
Trick to catch the old one
When you see me, you will know me
